questions.question: How do you design a normalized database schema? When would you denormalize, and why?
questions.canonical_answer: I design schemas using normalization rules (1NFâ€“3NF) to reduce redundancy and ensure integrity. I denormalize for performance when read speed or fewer joins are more important than storage efficiency.

questions.question: Describe strategies you use to optimize database performance.
questions.canonical_answer: I use indexing, query optimization, caching, partitioning, proper schema design, and resource tuning to improve performance.

questions.question: Explain how you would monitor and maintain database health in production.
questions.canonical_answer: I track performance metrics, slow queries, storage, replication status, backups, and error logs using monitoring tools and proactive alerts.

questions.question: How do you implement backup and recovery for critical databases? What strategies do you use for disaster recovery?
questions.canonical_answer: I use full, incremental, and point-in-time backups with automated schedules, and implement disaster recovery using replication, failover clusters, and offsite backups.

questions.question: How do you secure databases from unauthorized access and attacks?
questions.canonical_answer: I enforce strong authentication, role-based access, encryption, patching, firewalls, auditing, and least-privilege policies.

questions.question: Describe your experience with database replication and clustering. How do you ensure high availability?
questions.canonical_answer: I use master-slave or multi-master replication, clustering, and automatic failover to keep databases available and reduce downtime.

questions.question: How would you troubleshoot a slow-performing query or a locked table in a production environment?
questions.canonical_answer: I analyze execution plans, check locks, optimize indexes, rewrite queries, and kill blocking sessions if needed while preserving data safety.
